'''Micheline Bernardini''' (born 1927) is a former nude dancer at the [[Casino de Paris]] before being chosen by [[Louis RÃ©ard]] to model the first modern-day [[bikini]] on July 5, 1946 at [[Piscine Molitor]] in Paris.
==The first bikini== RÃ©ard could not find a model who would dare to wear his design. He ended up hiring Bernardini, a 19 year old [[striptease|nude dancer]] from the [[Casino de Paris]] as his model.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.bikiniscience.com/chronology/1945-1950_SS/LR4601_S/LR4601.html |title= Michele Bernadini: The First Bikini |first = Judson |last = Rosebush | work=Bikini Science | accessdate=September 17, 2008}}</ref><ref>EMILY MITCHELL, [http://www.time.com/time/international/1996/960701/fashion.html THE BIKINI TURNS 50], July 1, 1996 Volume 148, No. 1, [[Time Magazine]]</ref> That bikini, a string bikini with a [[g-string]] back made out of {{convert|30|sqin|cm2|0}} of cloth with newspaper type printed across, was "officially" introduced at a fashion event at [[Piscine Molitor]], a popular public pool in Paris. Her photographs from the show and stories of the event were widely publicized by the press. The ''[[Herald Tribune]]'' alone ran nine stories on the event.<ref>CLAUDIA A. MITCHELL and JACQUELINE REID-WALSH, ''Girl Culture: An Encyclopedia'', page 182, Greenwood Publishing Group, 2007, ISBN 0313084440</ref> The bikini was a hit, especially among men, and Bernardini received over 50,000 fan letters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history.do?action=VideoArticle&id=6949 |title=Bikini Introduced |accessdate=September 17, 2008 |publisher=[[A&E Television Networks]]}}</ref>
==Personal life== Bernardini later moved on to perform at the [[Tivoli Theatre (Sydney)|Tivoli Theater]] and was reported in newspapers as appearing in wild students' parties.<ref>Alan Lindsey McLeod, ''R.G. Howarth, Australian man of letters'', page 81, Sterling Publishers Pvt. Ltd, 2005, ISBN 1932705538</ref>
